advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Micro price, Mega features"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's new. It's the Hit-Bit" <br><br> "The computer according to Sony"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUSTAR NETWORK</strong></font><br><blockquote>Compustar is the network version of the SuperBrain. Each SuperBrain computer became an 'intelligent' video terminal called a Video Processing Unit and containing its own microprocessor and 64 KB of RAM. Single or double floppy disc could be added for 350 KB to 1.5 MB local storage. Up to 255 terminals could be connected into the same network. Maximum cable length between two terminal was one mile at a 1.6 MB data transfer rate. Each of them could share a disk storage system, from 10 to 96 MB with CP/M operating system. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken </b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL LEAFLET - INSIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERTISING PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 6000 MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> WE HAVE A NEW APPROACH TO DISTRIBUTED PROCESSING THAT WORKS <br><br> Already implemented are electronic mail, word processing, complete cost accounting with inventory control and more. The secret is a new technology called Functionally Structured Distribution (FSD). At last, a system to organize and manage distributed processing applications that is really up and running. FSD technology is especially applicable to installa­tions that require:<br> • Unlimited expandability supporting extremely large data bases and terminals in many cities.<br> • User-friendly software easily programmed in high level languages (COBOL, FORTRAN, and BASIC)<br> • System reliability (due to distributed hardware) while maintaining multiple levels of data security.<br> • Compatibility with existing mainframes and networks (including the Bell System). <br><br> We are presently installing Billings 6000 Computer Systems which take full advantage of distributed processing utilizing FSD technology. The 6000 Computer supports multiple hard disk drives with capacities of up to 64 Mbytes (formatted), streaming tapes for backup, auto-dial modems (2400 baud synchronous) for communications, and flexible disk drives for smaller installations.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>1982 - It was the time when one still lacked good programs for the IBM PC...<br><br> Advert said: <font color="#666666"><br><br> Attention, all programmers. Here's a chance to reach the top.<br> If you've written software that's completed and runs on the IBM Personal Computer (or another computer), we could be interested in publishing it...<br> ... We select programs that will make the IBM Personal Computer an even more useful toll for modern times...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND REVIEW</strong></font><br><blockquote>Review from a New Zealand magazine. Notice the prices in Australian$ at the bottom right of the page.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert shows all the tools a software developer could run on the MorthStar computers range (Horizon and Advantage) </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT (FEBRUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Goupil is an awesome manager"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DAK ADVERT (US, 1986) - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.dak.com" target="_blank">DAK</a> for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>John V. Blankenbaker designed the Kenbak-1 and marketed in the pages of Scientific American in 1971. The machine's name was taken from the middle of John's last name.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.vintage-computer.com" target="_blank">www.vintage-computer.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert from the ILLEL store</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Basis 108. Microcomputin'g "Best Of Both Worlds"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Sorry, you don't play with me"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CREATIVITY BUILT-IN</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a French advert from december 1985 for a special christmas pack : TO-7/70 + Microsoft Basic level 5 + tape recorder + Colorpaint + Basic initiation cube for "only" 3990 FF. <br><br> "All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Under all pictures of the promotional guide, you can read : "all screenshots are real and have not been retouched". <br><br> Really?</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PC-60</strong></font><br><blockquote>Photo taken from a Commodore brochure.<br> Notice that the girl seems not to be interested at all in the computer...</blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: one or two 3.5'' floppy drives (720 KB each)
computer.description:
IBM was struggling in 1986 against Apple's Macintosh series, so IBM set out to create something that would defeat the Macintosh. IBM came up with a all-in-one similar to the Macintosh. However, the Model 25 & 30 were the low-end (budget) models of the PS/2 range.
The PS/2 Model 25 became quite popular with businesses, but never made it strong with the home market.
The PS/2 Model 25 & 30 were the only system using the MCGA (Multicolor Graphics Adapter) standard. They came with this video features built-in. MCGA offered all text and graphic modes of the CGA standard plus 640x480 monochrome and 320x200, 256 colors (out of a palette of 262,144). It announced the future VGA standard which will become much more popular.
Model 25 & 30 were also the only PS/2 systems using an 8-bit ISA bus (like PC ATs), as opposed to other PS/2 models which used a 16 or 32 bit MCA bus.
Thanks to Alex Rushing for info and picture
Further information from Brandon: The model 25 came in two models, a monochrome model, and a color model. The monochrome model usually is called "Type 001", the color one being "Type 004".. There never was a type 002, or 003. The motherboard for the color and black and white models are exactly the same, minus some revisions on the later years. They were always surface mounted though (most of the chips anyway). They are a tough machine, though when you install one in a new room, it NEEDS to let sit in the room for a couple hours, otherwise the power supply/motherboard will die. While the floppy drives were 720KB, they "could" use 1.44MB drives, as long as the interface was the same. They contain TWO BIOS's in them. One called the CBIOS, and the other called the ABIOS.. CBIOS is "Compatible BIOS", and is used for DOS or Windows 3.0 and under... ABIOS, or "Advanced BIOS", is used when it runs OS/2.. OS/2 is the native OS to this unit. They also had an option for a hard drive.
computer.graphics: MCGA graphics : 640 x 480 in monochrome, 320 x 200 in 256 colours
computer.media: one or two 3.5'' floppy drives (720 KB each)
computer.name: PS/2 Model 25
computer.ports: Parallel port, 9pin serial port, 2 x ps/2 ports, 2 x internal expansion slots (8-bit)

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PS/2 RUNNING WINDOWS 3.0</strong></font><br><blockquote>Windows 3.0 running in high resolution with 16 shades of grey due to a VGA card installed.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Brandon for this picture</p></blockquote>
